info.name: Dispatch Connect: Playbook
info.description:
Purpose
-------

The purpose of the playbook is to provide you with step by step guidelines for connecting your system with Dispatch. This playbook is divided into the following sections:

* 3rd Party Contractor - Relevant if you're an enterprise with a contractor or 3rd party network
* SMB - Relevant if you're an SMB product solution provider and you wish to receive jobs and send updates via the Dispatch Platform
* General - General processing relevant to all use cases

Please refer to the relevant sections of the playbook as they will inform you of how to process the transactions that **you** care about. Therefore, this playbook is in every sense a "How To" guide and our experience has shown that if you adhere to it, you should be able to connect your system to Dispatch in a self sufficient manner. 

That said, we are of course here to help you with any questions that you might have. And  it's of course possible that we haven't covered every angle. If we encounter such a case, we will endeavor to make those updates to this documentation rather than address them in scattered emails and what not. In this sense, this is a living repository which will be updated as necessary to incorporate tweaks and enhancements as they become relevant and/or necessary.


Connector Hub
-------------
**Before proceeding any futher**, you should be reviewing our [Connector Hub documentation](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector) documentation. This resource will show you how to authenticate to the Dispatch Connect platform and includes some examples of how to send and receive data from Dispatch. 

The following diagram shows a high level interaction with the Dispatch Connect endpoints:

![Dispatch Connect](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8817368/39719546-38dab446-5242-11e8-9094-941cb1672a8f.png)


General Conventions
-------------------
* All date fields send to Dispatch should be an ISO timestamp unless expressly stated otherwise
* Addresses:
  * `country` is defaulted to `United States`. The only other valid value at the moment is `Canada` - which is actually the whole world if you go by "World Series"! We hope to start covering the World Cup soon
  * `state` accepts the 2 character acronym

Postman
-------
We decided to document this within  Postman as the environment is very easy to work with and provides an excellent way of documenting the APIs to boot! As such there are a few important things to note:

* You should download this playbook into your postman environment by clicking on the "Run in Postman" button on the top right
* Remember to choose your development language from the Language selector to have the API sample requests render in a relevant format. That may save you some development time.

item.name: 3rd Party
item.description: The scenarios described in this section are relevant to you if you're an enterprise with a contractor or 3rd party network.

item.name: To Dispatch
item.description:
As described in the [Connector Hub documentation](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector), you can send data in literally any format to Dispatch. If you do that, then it will be necessary to map from the structure that you are sending through to a structure that Dispatch understands. This exercise is typically performed by a member of the Dispatch ProServices team.

It might be better though if we can eliminate this mapping step altogether as this will allow you to start sending things over without any further ado. To this end, this section has some standard payload structures - if you adhere to these Dispatch Connect will know how to process them automatically. If you are sending custom payloads then please skip over the rest of this section.

request.description:
Overview
--------

We call it a Job. You might call it a Work Order, Service Order or something else. Potato, potﾄ》o. Anyway, you will be sending these over to us.

A job has the following main elements:

* Job Details
* Customer Details
* Service Provider/Contractor Details

Though we are quite forgiving, a job cannot really be a job without some basic information, so please take care to include the following details:

* Customer name (preferably first and last but we'll settle with whatever you can send us)
* Valid address (we need to know where to go!)
* Organization email and/or phone # (and/or organization `id` if you've pre-created those)

We will not create duplicate records. Meaning if you send over the same organization or customer record more than once, the system is smart enough to detect they exist. 

We'd also recommend you include a valid customer email and mobile number as that will enhance the experience. Do try to avoid invalid entries such as `jim@@abc.com` and `555123` as if you don't manage that we'll be forced to strip them before processing.

Oh and lastly, we'd really encourage sending over your unique IDs into the `external_id` fields for the job and organization. We might find it difficult to process updates without these.

Send this payload and voila - a job will be created in Dispatch!


Special Fields
--------------
Most of the fields in the payload should be self explanatory. But we do want to bring the following to your attention:

`job` section:
* `status` - the default mapping expects the following values:
  * `offered` - offers the job to the service provider
  * `accepted` - if you wish to accept on behalf of the service provider
  * `rejected` - as above
  * `completed` 
  * `canceled`
* `description` - this can accept [markdown](https://dillinger.io/) formatting

`suggested_times`-  This is an optional section, if you include it will offer the service provider these as "suggested times" that the customer has indicated are preferable.

`organization` (i.e. service provider):
* Only a single service provider record is currently supported
* If you're pre-creating service providers only the `id` or `external_id` needs to be supplied

Overview
--------

We call it an Organization. You might call it a Service Provider, Contractor, 3rd Party, Installer or something else. Tomato, tomﾄ》o.

Now the things is, you don't actually have to send these over to us separately. If you send these with the aforementioned job then we'll create them on the fly. However, sometimes it is preferred for these to be created separately in advance and if that's the case for you then you've come to the right place.

At a minimum, please ensure you provide us with the following bits of information (although the more the merrier of course):

* Name
* Valid Email and/or Phone Number

It's also really good practice to include your unique organization ID in the `external_id` attribute as then you can reference that when sending jobs over.

Oh and definitely the address. You see we use that to determine the time zone and if it's omitted we're forced to default to EST. So you may want to pass this so the guys in CA can sleep in a little bit.

Send this payload and Bob's your contractor!

item.name: From Dispatch
item.description:
Overview
--------

If you need to update your system based on updates made on the Dispatch platform then this section is for you! If you managed to successfully send a job to Dispatch Connect then you will be able to [sign in as a Dispatcher and Technician and work the job](https://www.screencast.com/t/uZ5DxiioftvJ).

The sections below list all the events that we think you'll need to be monitoring. If you encounter a case that you think is not covered, please reach out to us - there's a good chance we can configure it for you!

As a general rule, an event will only appear in the stream if it's something that originated from the Dispatch Platform. This means that we will not echo changes that originated from your system back to you!


Design Considerations
---------------------

Please note that the structures defined in this section are our default. If you already have your own preferred structure and/or format in which you prefer to receive the data, please let us know - there's a good chance we'll be able to accomodate you.

Please be aware that we may put additional events in the stream as our product evolves. Therefore you should be careful to incorporate the following into your design:

* Ignore any events that are not relevant to your use case (just [send an acknowledgement](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#sending-acknowledgements-to-dispatch) through)
* Although we will not *change* the names of attributes in the payload, it is possible that we'll add *new* attributes to the payload. Therefore make sure that your payload consumption will not break if a new attribute starts being included.


Event Summary
-------------

This section lists the events that are relevant to your use case and that can be retrieved [by polling the Connector Hub outbound endpoint](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#get-data-from-dispatch):

* Job
  * Job Accepted `job.unscheduled`
  * Job Declined `job.rejected` 
  * Job Completed: `job.complete` (Ready for Billing)
  * Job Paused: `job_paused` (e.g. No Show, Waiting for Parts)
  * Job Canceled: `job.canceled`
  * Job Created: `job.offered` (only necessary when the jobs do not get sent directly from your system)
* Appointment
  * Appointment Scheduled: `appointment.scheduled`
  * Technician Enroute: `appointment.enroute`
  * Appointment Started: `appointment.started`
  * Appointment Complete: `appointment.complete` *(only if you need to track at the appointment level - usually sufficient to use `job.complete`)*
  * Appointment Canceled: `appointment.canceled` *(only if you need to track at the appointment level - usually sufficient to use `job.canceled`)*
* Survey
  * Submitted by Customer: `survey.submitted`
* Notes/Attachments
  * Note: `note`
  * Attachment: `attachment`
  

Payload Structure
-----------------

The [Connector Hub documentation](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#get-data-from-dispatch) describes the overall payload structure and how to poll for them and to send through acknowledgement. The two elements from the payload that we care about for performing the processing mentioned in this section are the `Message/Request/Type` and `Message/Request/Payload`.

To be relevant for the processing mentioned in this section, ensure that the `Type` has a value of `put_data`. If it does then extract the `Payload` which will have the following basic payload structure:

    "Payload": {
        "Actions": [
            {
                "ID": null,
                "Put": {
                    "some_event": {
                        "id": 30462
                        "external_ids": [
                            "account.999.source:your_system_id"
                        ]
                        ...
                    }
                }
            }
        ]
    }


The following basics should be used for all event processing:
* `some_event` - Use this for your branch logic as described in the sections below. This can also be used to determine status.
* `external_id` - This is the Enterprise's record ID. This will appear in an array element.
* `updated_at` - Use this to mark the time the event occured in your system

request.description:
Overview
========

This describes the use cases for processing *Job* events. These events are wrapped in a `job` element. 

These are the cases that should be monitored:
* Accepted
* Rejected
* Completed (Ready for Billing)
* Paused  (e.g No Show, Waiting for Parts)
* Canceled
* Created (only if you are not sending jobs directly to Dispatch)

Job events have the following basic payload structure:

```
	"Payload": {
	    "Actions": [
	        {
	            "ID": null,
	            "Put": {
	                "job": {
	                    "id": 30462,
	                    "status": "some_status",
	                    "status_message": "some message",
	                    "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:05:46+0000",
	                    "external_ids": [
	                        "namespace:your_system_id"
	                    ]
	                }
	            }
	        }
	    ]
	}
```	


Event Processing
================

Job Accepted
------------

* Status: `unscheduled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Job Rejected
------------

* Status: `rejected`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * Retrieve the reject reason from the `status_message`

Job Completed
-------------

* Status: `complete`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * Retrieve the complete reason from the `status_message`

This event is generated in the following circumstances:
  * By completing an appointment using the "Ready for Billing" reason (and there are no other open appointment on the job)
  * By completing a job directly via the Dispatch Manage Portal

Therefore:
  * If all you need to monitor is whether a job is complete or not then you should process this event
  * If you want to track granularity at the appointment level then you should also process the appointment `complete` event (not required in most cases)

Note:
  * A follow up appointment can be created even after a job has been completed. If this happens another appointment `scheduled` event will be generated

Job Paused
----------

* Status: `paused`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * Retrieve the pause reason from the `status_message`

This event is generated in the following circumstances:
  * By completing an appointment as a "no show"
  * By completing an appointment as "waiting for parts"
  * Other pause events configured for your instance


Job Canceled
------------

* Status: `canceled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

This event is emitted when a job is canceled. Therefore:
  * If all you need to monitor is whether a job is canceled or not then you should subscribe to this event
  * If you want to track granularity at the appointment level then you should also subscribe to the appointment `canceled` event (not required in most cases)


Job Created
-----------

Sometimes jobs don't originate from you sending them directly to Dispatch. For example, if customers use a web page for requesting service those jobs could be sent to Dispatch. If you want to subscribe so that you can create them in your system then read on.

This event is a little beefier than other events as it contains the details of the job which you presumably want to copy to your system.

* Status: `offered`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

```
    "Payload": {
        "Actions": [
            {
                "ID": null,
                "Put": {
                    "job": {
                        "id": 30462,
                        "organization_id": 11776,
                        "title": " Claim Details 206",
                        "status": "offered",
                        "status_message": "",
                        "description": "some description",
                        "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:05:46+0000",
                        "service_type": "air conditioning",
                        "service_fee": 0,
                        "address": {
                            "street_1": "1755 Ridgeview Dr",
                            "street_2": "",
                            "postal_code": "76012",
                            "city": "Arlington",
                            "state": "TX",
                            "country": "United States",
                            "timezone": "America/Chicago",
                            "latitude": 32.7633905735029,
                            "longitude": -97.1352367468659
                        },
                        "external_ids": [
                            "your_system_id"
                        ],
                        "customer": {
                            "first_name": "James",
                            "last_name": "Dodd",
                            "company_name": "",
                            "email": "devs+dodd@dispatch.me",
                            "phone_number": "+15559803824"
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        ]
    }
```

Overview
========

This describes the use cases for processing *Appointment* events. These events are wrapped in an `appointment` element.

These are the cases that should be monitored:
* Scheduled
* Enroute
* Started
* Completed*
* Canceled*

*Only if appointment granularity is required, otherwise you should track these with the corresponding job events.

Appointment events have the following basic payload structure:

```    
	"Payload": {
	    "Actions": [
	        {
	            "ID": null,
	            "Put": {
	                "appointment": {
	                    "id": 18663,
	                    "status": "some_status",
	                    "job_id": 30463,
	                    "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:08:38+0000",
	                    "start_time": "2018-05-19T15:00:00+0000",
	                    "end_time": "2018-05-19T16:00:00+0000",
                        "job": {
                            "external_ids": [
                                "namespace:your_system_id"
                            ]
                        }
	                }
	            }
	        }
	    ]
	}
```    

Event Processing
================

Appointment Scheduled
---------------------

* Status: `scheduled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Enroute
-------------------

* Status: `enroute`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Started
-------------------

* Status: `started`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Completed
---------------------

* Status: `complete`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Canceled
--------------------

* Status: `canceled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

item.name: W2
item.description:
The scenarios described in this section are relevant to you if you're an enterprise with an internal workforce (W2).

The W2 connector requirements are similar to those of the 3rd Party. The only general differences are in the following areas:

**To Dispatch**

* Syncing of employee records - as an internal workforce is maintained, these need to be synced to Dispatch (create/update)
* Scheduling to an employee - in the W2 use case, you are often scheduling work directly to an employee from your source system. To accomodate, the job needs to include the appointment and assignment details. You should be able to schedule, reschedule, assign, re-assign, un-assign as necessary.


**From Dispatch**

* Contractors have the luxury of determining whether they want to take on the work sent their way. As such, there is typically an "accept" or "decline" option available. In the W2 use case not so much... Employees need to do the work that is sent their way. As such the aforementioned options are normally skipped and a job is immediately "scheduled" once it hits Dispatch



The above is of course "typical". Your use case may vary and if so we'd love to hear how so please reach out.

In order not to duplicate the documentation, we will only be documenting what is different to the 3rd party use case in this section. Where the use case is the same, we'll refer you to the corresponding 3rd party documentation.

item.name: To Dispatch
item.description:
As described in the [Connector Hub documentation](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector), you can send data in literally any format to Dispatch. If you do that, then it will be necessary to map from the structure that you are sending through to a structure that Dispatch understands. This exercise is typically performed by a member of the Dispatch ProServices team.

It might be better though if we can eliminate this mapping step altogether as this will allow you to start sending things over without any further ado. To this end, this section has some standard payload structures - if you adhere to these Dispatch Connect will know how to process them automatically. If you are sending custom payloads then please skip over the rest of this section.

request.description:
Overview
--------

We call it an Organization. You might call it a Franchise, Location, Office or something else. Tomato, tomﾄ》o.

Now the things is, you don't actually have to send these over to us separately. If you send these with the aforementioned job then we'll create them on the fly. However, in a typical W2 use case these are set up in advance and this section will tell you how to do just that.

At a minimum, please ensure you provide us with the following bits of information (although the more the merrier of course):

* Name
* Valid Email and/or Phone Number

It's also really good practice to include your unique organization ID in the `external_id` attribute as then you can reference that when sending jobs over.

Oh and definitely the address. You see we use that to determine the time zone and if it's omitted we're forced to default to EST. So you may want to pass this so the guys in CA can sleep in a little bit.

Overview
--------

We call it a User. You might call it an Employee, Tech or something else. 

If you maintain these users in your system of record you are going to want to keep them synchronized with Dispatch and this section will tell you how to do just that.

At a minimum, please ensure you provide us with the following bits of information (although the more the merrier of course):

* First and Last Name
* Valid Email and/or Phone Number
* `external_organization_id` to link it back the organization
* Roles - either `dispatcher` (someone who can see other peoples jobs), `technician` (someone who can only see/work jobs assigned to them) or both

It's also really good practice to include your unique user ID in the `external_id` attribute as then you can reference that when sending jobs over.

Overview
--------

We call it a Job. You might call it a Work Order, Service Order or something else. Potato, potﾄ》o. Anyway, you will be sending these over to us.

A job has the following main elements:

* Job Details
* Customer Details
* Service Provider/Contractor Details
* Appointment and assignment Details

Though we are quite forgiving, a job cannot really be a job without some basic information, so please take care to include the following details:

* Customer name (preferably first and last but we'll settle with whatever you can send us)
* Valid address (we need to know where to go!)
* Organization email and/or phone # (and/or organization `id` if you've pre-created those)

We will not create duplicate records. Meaning if you send over the same organization or customer record more than once, the system is smart enough to detect they exist. This therefore allows you, for example, to change the appointment time, assign and re-assign by just changing those values when sending the payload over.

We'd also recommend you include a valid customer email and mobile number as that will enhance the experience. Do try to avoid invalid entries such as `jim@@abc.com` and `555123` as if you don't manage that we'll be forced to strip them before processing.

Oh and lastly, we'd really encourage sending over your unique IDs into the `external_id` fields for the job, appointment, user and organization. We might find it difficult to process updates without these.

Send this payload and voila - a job will be created in Dispatch!


Special Fields
--------------
Most of the fields in the payload should be self explanatory. But we do want to bring the following to your attention:

`job` section:
* `status` - the default mapping expects the following values:
  * `offered` - offers the job to the service provider
  * `accepted` - if you wish to accept on behalf of the service provider
  * `rejected` - as above
  * `completed` 
  * `canceled`
* `description` - this can accept [markdown](https://dillinger.io/) formatting

`organization` (i.e. service provider):
* Only a single service provider record is currently supported
* If you're pre-creating service providers only the `id` or `external_id` needs to be supplied
  
`appointment`
* `time` - indicates the start window for the appointment (i.e. the earliest start time for the appointment window)
* `duration` - in seconds. The end time calculated from adding duration to the start time indicates the latest start time for the appointment window
* `status` - you generally want to set this to a value of `scheduled`
* If you have a single appointment to job then just set `external_id` to `external_job_id` to the same value
* `external_user_id` if you wish to assign or re-assign this should match the external ID you sent on the user record.

item.name: From Dispatch
item.description:
Overview
--------

If you need to update your system based on updates made on the Dispatch platform then this section is for you! If you managed to successfully send a job to Dispatch Connect then you will be able to [sign in as a Dispatcher and Technician and work the job](https://www.screencast.com/t/uZ5DxiioftvJ).

The sections below list all the events that we think you'll need to be monitoring. If you encounter a case that you think is not covered, please reach out to us - there's a good chance we can configure it for you!

As a general rule, an event will only appear in the stream if it's something that originated from the Dispatch Platform. This means that we will not echo changes that originated from your system back to you!


Design Considerations
---------------------

Please note that the structures defined in this section are our default. If you already have your own preferred structure and/or format in which you prefer to receive the data, please let us know - there's a good chance we'll be able to accomodate you.

Please be aware that we may put additional events in the stream as our product evolves. Therefore you should be careful to incorporate the following into your design:

* Ignore any events that are not relevant to your use case (just [send an acknowledgement](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#sending-acknowledgements-to-dispatch) through)
* Although we will not *change* the names of attributes in the payload, it is possible that we'll add *new* attributes to the payload. Therefore make sure that your payload consumption will not break if a new attribute starts being included.


Event Summary
-------------

This section lists the events that are relevant to your use case and that can be retrieved [by polling the Connector Hub outbound endpoint](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#get-data-from-dispatch):

* Job
  * Job Completed: `job.complete` (Ready for Billing)
  * Job Paused: `job_paused` (e.g. No Show, Waiting for Parts)
  * Job Canceled: `job.canceled`
  * Job Created: `job.offered` (only necessary when the jobs do not get sent directly from your system)
* Appointment
  * Appointment Scheduled: `appointment.scheduled`
  * Technician Enroute: `appointment.enroute`
  * Appointment Started: `appointment.started`
  * Appointment Complete: `appointment.complete` *(only if you need to track at the appointment level - usually sufficient to use `job.complete`)*
  * Appointment Canceled: `appointment.canceled` *(only if you need to track at the appointment level - usually sufficient to use `job.canceled`)*
* Survey
  * Submitted by Customer: `survey.submitted`
* Notes/Attachments
  * Note: `note`
  * Attachment: `attachment`
  

Payload Structure
-----------------

The [Connector Hub documentation](https://docs.dispatch.me/connector/#get-data-from-dispatch) describes the overall payload structure and how to poll for them and to send through acknowledgement. The two elements from the payload that we care about for performing the processing mentioned in this section are the `Message/Request/Type` and `Message/Request/Payload`.

To be relevant for the processing mentioned in this section, ensure that the `Type` has a value of `put_data`. If it does then extract the `Payload` which will have the following basic payload structure:

    "Payload": {
        "Actions": [
            {
                "ID": null,
                "Put": {
                    "some_event": {
                        "id": 30462
                        "external_ids": [
                            "account.999.source:your_system_id"
                        ]
                        ...
                    }
                }
            }
        ]
    }


The following basics should be used for all event processing:
* `some_event` - Use this for your branch logic as described in the sections below. This can also be used to determine status.
* `external_id` - This is the Enterprise's record ID. This will appear in an array element.
* `updated_at` - Use this to mark the time the event occured in your system

Overview
========

This describes the use cases for processing *Job* events. These events are wrapped in a `job` element. 

These are the cases that should be monitored:
* Completed (Ready for Billing)
* Paused  (e.g No Show, Waiting for Parts)
* Canceled
* Created (only if you are not sending jobs directly to Dispatch)

Job events have the following basic payload structure:

```
	"Payload": {
	    "Actions": [
	        {
	            "ID": null,
	            "Put": {
	                "job": {
	                    "id": 30462,
	                    "status": "some_status",
	                    "status_message": "some message",
	                    "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:05:46+0000",
	                    "external_ids": [
	                        "namespace:your_system_id"
	                    ]
	                }
	            }
	        }
	    ]
	}
```	


Event Processing
================

Job Completed
-------------

* Status: `complete`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * Retrieve the complete reason from the `status_message`

This event is generated in the following circumstances:
  * By completing an appointment using the "Ready for Billing" reason (and there are no other open appointment on the job)
  * By completing a job directly via the Dispatch Manage Portal

Therefore:
  * If all you need to monitor is whether a job is complete or not then you should process this event
  * If you want to track granularity at the appointment level then you should also process the appointment `complete` event (not required in most cases)

Note:
  * A follow up appointment can be created even after a job has been completed. If this happens another appointment `scheduled` event will be generated

Job Paused
----------

* Status: `paused`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * Retrieve the pause reason from the `status_message`

This event is generated in the following circumstances:
  * By completing an appointment as a "no show"
  * By completing an appointment as "waiting for parts"
  * Other pause events configured for your instance


Job Canceled
------------

* Status: `canceled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

This event is emitted when a job is canceled. Therefore:
  * If all you need to monitor is whether a job is canceled or not then you should subscribe to this event
  * If you want to track granularity at the appointment level then you should also subscribe to the appointment `canceled` event (not required in most cases)


Job Created
-----------

Sometimes jobs don't originate from you sending them directly to Dispatch. For example, if customers use a web page for requesting service those jobs could be sent to Dispatch. If you want to subscribe so that you can create them in your system then read on.

This event is a little beefier than other events as it contains the details of the job which you presumably want to copy to your system.

* Status: `offered`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

```
    "Payload": {
        "Actions": [
            {
                "ID": null,
                "Put": {
                    "job": {
                        "id": 30462,
                        "organization_id": 11776,
                        "title": " Claim Details 206",
                        "status": "offered",
                        "status_message": "",
                        "description": "some description",
                        "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:05:46+0000",
                        "service_type": "air conditioning",
                        "service_fee": 0,
                        "address": {
                            "street_1": "1755 Ridgeview Dr",
                            "street_2": "",
                            "postal_code": "76012",
                            "city": "Arlington",
                            "state": "TX",
                            "country": "United States",
                            "timezone": "America/Chicago",
                            "latitude": 32.7633905735029,
                            "longitude": -97.1352367468659
                        },
                        "external_ids": [
                            "your_system_id"
                        ],
                        "customer": {
                            "first_name": "James",
                            "last_name": "Dodd",
                            "company_name": "",
                            "email": "devs+dodd@dispatch.me",
                            "phone_number": "+15559803824"
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        ]
    }
```

Overview
========

This describes the use cases for processing *Appointment* events. These events are wrapped in an `appointment` element.

These are the cases that should be monitored:
* Scheduled
* Enroute
* Started
* Completed*
* Canceled*

*Only if appointment granularity is required, otherwise you should track these with the corresponding job events.

Appointment events have the following basic payload structure:

```    
	"Payload": {
	    "Actions": [
	        {
	            "ID": null,
	            "Put": {
	                "appointment": {
	                    "id": 18663,
	                    "status": "some_status",
	                    "job_id": 30463,
	                    "updated_at": "2018-05-18T10:08:38+0000",
	                    "start_time": "2018-05-19T15:00:00+0000",
	                    "end_time": "2018-05-19T16:00:00+0000",
                        "job": {
                            "external_ids": [
                                "namespace:your_system_id"
                            ]
                        }
	                }
	            }
	        }
	    ]
	}
```    

Event Processing
================

Appointment Scheduled
---------------------

* Status: `scheduled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Enroute
-------------------

* Status: `enroute`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Started
-------------------

* Status: `started`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Completed
---------------------

* Status: `complete`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

Appointment Canceled
--------------------

* Status: `canceled`
* Additional processing recommended:
  * None

item.name: SMB
item.description:
The scenarios in this section are relevant to you if you're an SMB product solution provider and you wish to receive jobs and send updates via the Dispatch Platform.

The general standard flow for this use case is as follows:

1. Enterprise sends a job to Dispatch
2. You poll the connector to pick this job and process into your system
3. You send through updates which typically include :
	* Milestone status e.g. accept, scheduled, complete
	* Notes

The exception flow for this use case is as follows:

1. Enterprise sends through a cancelation
2. You send through a cancelation

**Whether you choose to implement all are part of these use cases (or beyond) is up to you.**

item.name: From Dispatch
To Dispatch
item.description:
Updates you send back to Dispatch will be sent back through to the Enterprise. This section describes the updates that we are looking to receive. Though we encourage sending over all updates you deem relevant, the following is the recommended minimum set of updates:

1. Acceptance - assuming you have an acceptance step
2. Schedule
3. Complete

It would be also be very beneficial to receive notes too.

Please note that the structures defined in this section are our default. If you already have your own preferred structure and/or format in which you prefer to receive the data, please let us know - there's a good chance we'll be able to accomodate you.

request.description:
When you send through a status update send over the following:

```
    [{
		"header": {
			"record_type": "job",
			"version": "v3"
		},
		"record": {
			"id": 555,
			"status": "accepted"
		}
	}]
```	


Please try to map the `status` to one of the following values:

* **accepted** - job is accepted by Service Provider
* rejected - job is rejected by Service Provider
* enroute
* started
* **completed**
* canceled

Values in the list above appearing in bold are the critical job milestone statuses that should be sent over to make the connector effort valuable. The others are optional (but recommended if you have them).

item.name: General
item.description: Some general processing relevant to all connector types.

item.name: Ack/Error
item.description: The processing mentioned in this section is optional.
